Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 07:33PM - edited Jan 14, 2009 07:35PM by lexislove thisisme, I think the 5% stat your surgon gave you was for a LOCAL recurrence. Ex. it returning in the breast. When people talk about " recurrences" there is local (confined to the breast), regional (surrounding tissues ie.lymph nodes) and distant ( other organs). Even though having a mastectomy reduces your cance of a LOCAL recurrence greatly, they can not completely remove all breast tissue. I think that they can remove 90-95% of it. So there is still that risk , the 5% given to you that it may come back. The "healthy breast" having a prophylatic mastectomy would reduce that 15% chance given to you, but AGAIN they cant remove every little bit of breast tissue. I hope I could make sense, its a very good question that I asked as well. I'm sure others will come along to explaine in better detail.
Posts.Title: Risk reduction with proph mastectomy and other stat questions thisisme ailenroc

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 08:06PM - edited Jan 14, 2009 08:29PM by lexislove thisisme, At your surgery they will removesome lymph nodes to determine if there is or was cancer in them.I think I read on here before that in only 15% of the time there is a complete response to chemo, ie. no cancer remaining in the breast or nodes. Even though you had chemo first,the pathologist can tell if cancer had been involved at a given time. I had 28 rads myself and I did bring up to my onc about doing a bilateral. He said, not unless I tested positive for the BRCA gene. I asked what my risk for a "new"breast cancer and he said 20-30% LIFETIME risk. I'm 30 by the way. So...the way I look at it is 70-80% I won't get it. I'm also ER+ so I'm taking Tamoxifen to help reduce the risk of a "new" breast cancer. I think...IF I was to develop another breast cancer it would be caught a lot sooner than this one and maybe my treatment won't be so invasive as this one that I just went through. It is a very tough decision, but I feel I made the best one. I wrestle with this everyday.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 09:08AM - edited May 9, 2010 09:12AM by lexislove mom, Well...theoretically, I can't take Tamox either (poor metabolizer) but there is so..so much contoversy with this test. Especially with pre menopausal woman because Tamox is THE only thing we can take. My onc explained to me that a poor metabolizer does not mean NO metabolzer. It just means it takes longer for the Tamox to do it's thing and how much I'm actually metabolizing? We don't know. So. What does that mean for me? Well, I don't want to be my own trial and "see what happens". Forget it. So, since I'm only 32 and still highly premenopausal, I decided to get the ovaries out now, than later. I asked my onc what I was suppose to do. Take the Lupron untill I hit natural menopause? Pfffttt....ok. That could be another 15 yrs! Plus, my Lupron is only covered for the first 3 yrs since finishing treatment. Why? Because studies to date only have this info, overall survival with 3 yrs of Lupron vs nothing. The SOFT trial will answer all these questions for us pre meno woman.The SOFT trial will be answering for 5 yrs and if Lupron with Tamox is better than Lupron with an AI. Or Tamox is just fine. I asked my onc straight out, "what do you think I should do?" My onc said very honestly, that with us pre meno woman they ,the reasearchers,just don't know enough right now. AND....any news regarding the SOFT trial will be years away. mom.....I can't wait years and take a gamble. I have to do what I know now. Most of it, is my own research, other womans stories I've read on various B.C. boards and my own gut feeling. So thats me. As for testing estrogen levels...it's a blood test. I do not get my estrogen levels checked, but I don't need to because I'm on Tamox still. Even though I'm on the Lupron, if I did test and it said that I wasn't fully in menopause, thats ok......being on the Tamox. NOT, the AI. Tamox and Ai's work differently. Tamox binds on to the estrogen in our bodies, where an AI....stops to help the production. Edit: Our bodies also produce estrogen in our adrenal glands and excess fat. Thats why they say a reducing excess weight and exercising to keep off the pounds will help lower our chances of developing BC or getting a recurrence.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2010 10:45PM lexislove wrote: HI there. My questions were the same...I decided to remove them. Im 32, done with kids and there is no research to tell me how long to stay on the Lupron for. Do I take Lupron shots every 3 months for 15 yrs or more? Come on now...really. I think age has to do with your decision too. There are pros and cons with removing the ovaries. For instance removal is permanent, there is no going back. Being thrown into menopause right away instead of gradually. Increase risk of heart disease and bone loss. These can be prevented through lifestyle though. Its a hard decision...do whats right for you.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 07:28PM lexislove wrote: I've been doing Lupron since June 2008. I do the every 3 month shot. It's ok. I like only going to the cancer centre every 3 months instead of every. I do have se's but I've linked it to the Tamox. momand2kids, Are you having your estrogen levels tested monthly to make sure that you are in full menopause? I hope you are...because the AI's will only work if you are fully menopausal. Even though we are supressing our ovaries, have had no period doesn't gurantee we are fully in menopause. This is very...very important. If you are NOT in full menopause...the AI's can actually stimulate the ovaries. So you actually doing more harm than good. I was told this by my onc, when I tested as a poor metabolizer via the cyp2d6 test. I was ready to throw the Tamox away and start up Femara. I actually DID do Femara for 2 weeks...then my onc told me that it was safer for me to do the Tamox than the AI untill I have my ooph (June 3rd). I asked about testing my estrogen levels, I think I remember him saying there was 2 hormones that need to be seen as menopausal, but apparantly in Canada...it's not available. There is literature on this on the net if you want to google yourself.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 12:17PM - edited Oct 28, 2009 12:21PM by lexislove There are so may factors when it comes to ones prognosis. - Age, pre-existing health conditions, Er & Her2 status, tumor grade, response to chemo if one had neo adjuvant chemo, multi focal disease,lymphatic invasion and the most important.....number of lymph nodes involved. These will all affect a womans long term survival. I also believe changing ones lifestyle can help as well. Exercise, proper weight and good food choices has an affect. As for stats.......Im gonna say it.....ready? They are what they are and so is ones diagnosis / path report. Do I believe in stats? No. People beat stats every day. You are always gonna read NEW studies regarding the proper chemo for certain cancers ect...ect. But you had the best treatment at that time. We cant go back and change our treatment or get worried that we had one chemo but news is saying the other MAY be better....it will make one mad. As for AI's they are relativly NEW, compared with Tamox so data isnt definitive...but we have a pretty good idea that they work great! As for Herceptin, the long term news will hopefully be out soon. Im Her2, I have various studies to show prognosis regarding myself.....but those studies are only 3 yr. Do I sit and worry about year 4-8? No. Do I wonder? Sure. I think if someone really wants to know their prognosis, the best person to ask is their onc. The onc knows ones specific case....and even then.....they have no crystal ball. Be well.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2009 11:05AM - edited Nov 25, 2009 11:07AM by lexislove I am a young woman diagnosed with BC. You all already know that.... I think I am one of the minority of young woman to NOT opt for a bilateral mastectomy. I asked all my docs, and they all said no. My surgeon said that same thing as caaclarks..." you could get cancer of the lung or brain but are we going to cut it off to try to prevent....no." Iam though ER+, and have changed my lifestyle habits , I had good babits before I just need some fine tuning...all things that help reduce recurrence. Im also planning an ooph. I  have thought If I was to remove the healthy breast and develop BC in it, it would probably be at the chest wall because most of the tissue had been removed . VS NOT removing the tissue and having a "new primary" caught earlier and easier to treat. This is MY rationing. Is it right? Who knows. But I feel better in my decision. I am getting a lift/reduction on my healthy breast to match my implant and my PS assures me that I will be happy. I have also seen pics of other survivors who have had his work. I must add though, if I was TN or obviously had one of the BRCA genes, I would be doing a bilateral.

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 12:50AM lexislove wrote: ShellyJo, good response to the chemo! There was a study done on SLN biopsies after neo adjuvant chemo to see if diagnosis is the same regarding lymph nodes for pre chemo and post chemo. The study concluded that a SLN biopsy performed AFTER chemo is just as accurate at deteriming lymph node status as if a SLN biopsy was performed pre chemo. So ...you must likely only had 1 lymph node involved. Remember the false positives for scans play into pre chemo scan as well.It is very...very..difficult for any scan to single out lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 07:33PM - edited Mar 23, 2009 07:35PM by lexislove At the beginning I wasn't sure about my onc. He is 38 and I always had this image in my head of an "older"doc. But after a few months, he kinda grew on me. Now...I think he is wonderful. He is very honest with me, and takes his time answering my questions. He is also very aggressive with treatments. He suggested Lupron and Zometa right away. I know 2 other girls my age and their onc's have them on Tamoxifen only and will not put them on to Zometa without more "proof" even though studies have said otherwise. One example of why I think he is so great: It was 2 weeks from after finishing my rads. I was freaked....crying everyday, scared. Oneday I got so freaked out that I made something in my head to beleive he was not "telling me everything". You see I was misdiagnosed by doctor dumba$$ so my trust in any doctor was nil. I called his receptionist crying, she asked if I could come down later that afternoon to see him. I said, "are you kidding me I can't drive!" she then said she'll get him to call me. He called me in 10 minutes , calmed me down and was very positive with my prognosis.  He actually said..."you have to trust me,I don't know why you think you are going to die." I see you being an old lady in her Volkswagen." he also told me NOT to go searching on the net about stuff and only HE knows my diagnosis. So if I have any questions , ask him only.  I was sooo happy. And thanked him gratiously. Now..when I see him for my checks....we mostly talk about travelling. lol. Just how you feeling? Blah blah....I feel fortunate to have him as my onc.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2009 02:58PM lexislove wrote: I have never heard of just the TH.Is this new or in trials? You have a small tumor so it might be quite ok. The AC has a slightly high risk for heart problems later on, so if you already have heart issues ect or are older, I would advise to not do the AC. Why risk it ..when the TCH has the same benefit. AC is a powerfull combo that has been shown to be superior when treating Her2+ tumors but studies have shown that the TCH shows similar results. Ask about the TCH for 4 treatments or 6 at your next onc visit. Herceptin will be given every 3 weeks. Congrats on your path report..sounds good!

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2010 06:08AM - edited Jan 11, 2010 06:23AM by lexislove Kerry is right, Going through treatment and a few weeks after treatment.....I had waaaaaay more bad days than good. What helped was basically getting back to my normal activities. At the time it was taking my 3 yr old to the park, grocery shopping, house duties, getting out with friends for lunch. Getting back to a normal helped me feel positive. As the time moves on, those bad days are less.  I have now anxiety days, going for a mammogram, onc check ups. But those come few, and when they are over I dont even think about them. I look forward, not back. I have done all treatment to date. I have been aggressive. Chemo,mastectomy,rads,Herceptin,Lupron,Zometa, Tamox and will be switching to an AI. I have to feel confident that I will be ok. The odds are in my favor....yours too.

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2009 01:34AM lexislove wrote: Hi there! Reading your post brought me back over 2 yrs ago. I know the fear. Please dont freak out because the size of your tumor. Mine was 8cm and I did neo adjuvant chemo too. It shrunk to about 1.3cm by 1.3cm. With DCIS present. My onc was very pleased at the response and at surgery my surgeon was able to get clear margins. I cried to my onc about the size of my tumor and these were his words: Its not really the size of the tumor thats important, its how well you respond to the treatment and what they find at the time of your surgery (clear margins,lymph nodes clear). I was Her2+ too. And Her2 disease responds really,really well to chemo. You will also be having Herceptin and that is probably the most important thing for you to do. The beginning is the worse. But you will get to a point where you will just be focussed on treatment and being healthy again. I am almost 28 months out from diagnosis and 2 yrs out from finishing chemo and surgery. My life is back. My energy is back. I feel strong and healthy again. You will be there too.Promise. If you have questions just ask.

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2010 12:22PM lexislove wrote: Pure, I had the same worries, Im sure we all have at some point. But, like mary said, you have to believe the treatment has worked.......and leave it. This is what I did, I wrote down on a piece of paper everything I did and am doing. Chemo,Mastectomy, rads, Herceptin, OS/Tamox and Zometa. Now an ooph... I then also put beside the % beside each that helps reduce my recurrence rate. I then put it up on my fridge. Yes, the fridge. Everytime I had doubt or was scared I looked at that paper. Its funny Im talking about this, I had my paper up on my fridge for 2 yrs. I looked at it many times....but Saturday I started my spring cleaning and threw it out. My fridge was cluttered with my daughters preschool art work and I asked myself. " do you still NEED this? wouldn't having another of Lexi's art work look nicer on the fridge?"  YES! My point being, I did then, what I had to do to get through tough times. Those times are gone, well not completely Im just more confident in my treatment and prognosis now. Be well.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 10:31PM lexislove wrote: I just wanted to clarify, that I not once have never made any statement like " thank god my nodes were negative!" or around those lines.  For the first 6 months of my diagnosis my docs, and I, expected positive lymph nodes due to my tumor size. I was doing neo adjuvant chemo. My onc said I had a 10% chance of my nodes being negative. He said he had seen cases with large breast tumors before and no nodes.....but the majority of the time they are positive. I came on the boards and saw all these little 1cm tumors no nodes blah blah...and felt like crap.  Well....I fell in that 10% of being node negative. Luck? Maybe I dunno. My point is I know how those "thank god" statements sting. And I don't feel any better off than a woman with 1 or more positive nodes. I know how this disease can be unpredictable and sneaky. there are no gurantees. My BC was aggressive end of discussion. Im glad this forum has been started.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2010 04:33PM lexislove wrote: I do know that it is common to still have positive nodes AFTER neo adjuvant chemo. There are many woman here that has had that happen. Why? there is a theory that the chemo works better on bulk tumors (the main tumor). This doesnt mean that the chemo won't work for you. The Taxol maybe the chemo that clears things up. Look at it this way, your tumor responded to the AC and has shrunk. Its better than if it didnt respond or grew. Your at the half way mark still got more chemo to do...nothings definitive till you have had surgery and have your pathology report. Scans are not too reliable either right now. Its hard for scan to pick up single nodes...and to give an exact explanation to what is actually going on. The wait is hard...I know. I had neo adjuvant too. But...really you have to wait till pathology to find out for sure. One thing though...chemo works excelllent on TN tumors. Better than Er+. Dont give up yet!

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 05:34PM - edited Feb 26, 2010 05:41PM by lexislove Every PS is different. And, they all have their own opinion about what is right or wrong. There are a lot of woman who have had tissue expanders in place during rads. I am one of them. I agree that tissue expanders can affect the rad field....but that is why you dont get fills during rads. You wait till rads are over, and the skin is feeling/looking better to continue. I waited 8 weeks post rads to continue with fills. I was expanded to 250cc's starting rads. Are you wanting to be a D cup with your final reconstruction? Is that the reasoning for the back thingy? What if you were to decide being a C cup? Its up to you...just more surgery ect. Second opinion might be a good idea too. BTW: I was also a D cup. DD to my PS. I went to a C cup and its so...so...much better.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2009 01:34PM lexislove wrote: Shana, I will try to answer these questions, but not 100% sure: 1) I dont think there are any studies out to determine if using Zometa on the bones prevents it going to the lungs,liver,brain. I was told by my onc, that if BC was to metastasize it 70% of the time it will go to the bones first. So maybe stopping the cancer going to the bones first will help prevent further spread. Good question. I never really asked. I was just happy to be taking anything to help reduce risk more. Zometa also has a long shelf life. So I was told if you are taking the infusions for 3 yrs,like most early stage woman will do, you still will get the benefit of Zomeat 10-15 yrs more. As for the AI, in the beginning I forgot my Tamox every now and then. After a few months when the anti hormones are in your system, forgetting a day will not affect you. Its multiple days or weeks. If you forget?Just take it when you remember.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 12:02AM - edited Jul 11, 2009 12:39AM by lexislove Carol, I remember your earlier posts! I'm so happy you are happy with your second opinion!!!!!! This second onc seems to be on his "game" Good for you.Let us know how your surgery went ok? ameron, it is true that chemo works very well on agressive cancers. The positive receptor thing and response to chemo is actually the other way around. There is talk that ER+ woman actually benefit MORE from Tamox or an AI than chemo.That doesn't mean though that chemo doesnt work at all though. Being Her2 positive is agressive too so chemo combined with the Herceptin will really do a number on you BC. Only 20% of woman who have chemo before surgery have a cPR (complete pathological response) so even if you have some remaining tumor...your not doomed. As for chemo getting to the nodes...rare too. Chemo tends to attack the tumor bulk, its called tumor load.It is not uncommon to have positive nodes AFTER chemo. \ Carol, when you have your surgery and if the nodes are clear? Most likely you only had 2 involved.There was a study that came out of the St.Gallens Oncology Conference this spring that looked at SLN biopsy's before chemo and after chemo in woman.They concluded that SLN biopsy's performed AFTER chemo was just as good at determining lymph node status in woman.Especially those with a cPR.

My first infusion I was achy a couple of hours after the injection...but I just took an extra strength tylenol and was good. Second infusion...nothing I went rollerblading. It's up to you if you want to do the trial or not...maybe weigh the pros and cons. But in the end I think Zometa is an excellent addition to your adjuvant care! ~* thake care *~ Sam

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 03:13PM lexislove wrote: You will most likely have a CT scan before starting rads...to help map out things. And yes, the tatoos....they were the same appointment for me. I also met my rad onc the same day. They talk about what to expect with rads and skin care. they will give it all to you in writing too. When rads started....I met with my rad onc once a week. It was very quick...just "hi, how are you, how are you doing/feeling?" Stuff like that. I saw my rad onc only 5 times. I was suppose to see her 3 months post rads, but cancelled because my anxiety was too much going back down to the BIG cancer centre. Rads by far easier than chemo for me. It was harder mentally though (for me). Like I said, I had to go to the big centre....I saw so many cancer patients and I was always the youngest. My hair was short, and all the ladies in the waiting area had hair, and their breasts and were at least twice my age.  I would over hear them complaining about there DCIS diagnosis...* I hope no DCIS ladies rant on me..lol* I wanted to scream. I left almost daily with tears in my eyes. Thats just my experience though

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 09:57PM - edited Dec 1, 2009 09:58PM by lexislove So now what? You go on with your life. You say to yourself ,"I have had the best treatment to date, and I am still getting treatment (Tamox/AI, Zometa). You believe in the treatment and that you are going to live a long life. I went through the exact same feelings you are right now. EXACT. I finished Herceptin November 2008. I was done.Finished.Onc said, "see you in 3 months, heres your Tamox." Ummmmm....ok. I focused on Christmas. 2007 Christmas I was going through chemo, so 2008 christmas I was going to make special. I took my daughter to have pictures with Santa.I made holiday gifts ect...ect. It helped take my mind of my whole BC experience. It is literally a one day at a time thing. The more that time passes...the less you think of BC and the fear that comes with it. Things do get easier...trust me. I wish I could wave a magic wand....for all of us.
